summary:
I am a chemical engineer with a passion for sustainability. Because of this I moved to the Netherlands to pursue a MSc and PhD in renewable energy technologies. Throughout this path I have been able to combine a solid academic background with hands-on practical experience.  I enjoy learning new skills and working on multidisciplinary projects where communication skills are important to move forward. 

I've been involved in different projects related to sustainability and leadership, connecting with people all over the world to gain a better understanding of the energy tranistion and the skills necessary to accelerate it. I am looking forward for new opportunities to use these skills in practical applications to make a difference.

awards: [{'title': 'Marina van Damme Grant', 'description': 'The Marina van Damme Grant is awarded each year to talented female alumni from Delft University of Technology, Eindhoven University of Technology, the University of Twente or Wageningen University. With this grant, Marina van Damme wants to enable young female engineers to further develop themselves and to increase their career opportunities. The grant is intended to help winners to broaden their knowledge or explore international opportunities in the form of a study programme, internship or project in the Netherlands or abroad.', 'issuer': None, 'date': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}}, {'title': 'Honors Program', 'description': 'The Honors Program consists of 20 ECTS: an individual part of 15 ECTS and a collective part of 5 ECTS. The collective part consists of a course called Critical Reflection on Technology. For the individual part I followed courses on the Hydrogen Production and Storage track for the Sustainable Energy Technology Masters Program. \nThe academic requirements include a GPA of 7.5 or more, and a total duration of the Masters Program of maximum 2 years. ', 'issuer': 'TU Delft', 'date': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}}]

projects: [{'title': 'Systematic comparison of a-Si:H and a-SiC:H devices as photocathodes', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'In the Photovoltaic Materials and Devices (PVMD) research group, an amorphous silicon carbide (a-SiC:H) photocathode is used to drive the production of hydrogen on its surface [1]. Current literature shows the use of an amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) photocathode for this use [2]. However, these have yet to be compared to determine the most appropriate semiconductor material. Thus, a systematic comparison of both must be performed to determine which photocathode has a better performance. This comparison represents the scope of this project. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Andrea', 'last_name': 'Mangel Raventos', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Innovation Consultant at PNO Chemistry'}]}, {'title': 'Substitute Natural Gas Production in a Fluidized Bed', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'The goal of this project was to design an industrial-sized reactor in which the conversion of syngas from a biomass source into Substitute Natural Gas in a fluidized bed reactor takes place.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Andrea', 'last_name': 'Mangel Raventos', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Innovation Consultant at PNO Chemistry'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Elisabeth', 'last_name': 'Insam', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Renewable Energy Engineer'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Robin', 'last_name': 'Guarnotta', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Edge software engineer focused on renewables, storage and electric vehicles'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Antía', 'last_name': 'Varela Souto', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Product Owner Power & Energy at Vanderlande'}]}, {'title': 'Applied Sciences Faculty PV System Design', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'description': 'The goal of this project was to design a grid-connected PV System to supply part of the energy consumption of the Applied Sciences Faculty in TU Delft. This was done by developing a MATLAB code to optimize the module orientation and the power electronic components of the system. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Andrea', 'last_name': 'Mangel Raventos', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Innovation Consultant at PNO Chemistry'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Antía', 'last_name': 'Varela Souto', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Product Owner Power & Energy at Vanderlande'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Albert', 'last_name': 'Bassa', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Team Lead Power Electronics @ Ferroamp Elektronik AB'}]}, {'title': 'Photoelectrochemical water splitting: development of a silicon carbide photoelectrode', 'date': {'start': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}}, 'description': 'Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting was studied as a possible process for generating solar fuels. In this way, it is possible to generate hydrogen from solar energy and water. These are widely available on Earth, and can be harnessed to solve the current energy crisis. To do this, a photocathode and a photoanode made of hydrogenated amorphous silicon carbide were fabricated and tested. ', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Andrea', 'last_name': 'Mangel Raventos', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Innovation Consultant at PNO Chemistry'}]}, {'title': 'Determination of kinetic growth behavior of filamentous cyanobacteria Leptolyngbya sp. for water treatment.', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The main goal of this project was the determination of the kinetic growth behavior of filamentous cyanobacteria Leptolyngbya sp. This was done in three experimental phases, developed in the CIBCM at The University of Costa Rica. The different factors that affect the growth of this cyanobacteria were studied thoroughly to understand their effect on the development.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Andrea', 'last_name': 'Mangel Raventos', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Innovation Consultant at PNO Chemistry'}]}]
